info.document:
It is an anomaly of US presidential elections that the country's most populous state rarely has much of a say in who the two party nominees are.

But all that is about to change as California, the sleeping giant of White House races, looks set to take a starring role in deciding which Democrat will take on Donald Trump, the almost certain Republican standard bearer, in 2020.

The Golden State is planning to move its primary elections, in which its 40 million people will make their choices, from the end of the calendar to the start.

By the time its primary was held in the 2016 race both Hillary Clinton, and Mr Trump, had already secured the party nominations.

It was the sixth time in seven campaigns that California, the world's sixth largest economy just behind the UK, proved completely irrelevant.

Alex Padilla, California's Secretary of State, said: "We're the most populous state in the nation, the most diverse state in the nation, with the largest economy of any state in the nation.

"We should have much more of a say in who the nominees for president are."

Under the plan the California primary will move from June to March. It will be after Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and South Carolina, but will award far more delegates than all of those states combined.

The delegates will be awarded to candidates proportionally, but the winner will be given a flying start and huge momentum.

Election experts believe that winner will then attract most of the money pouring in from Democrat donors, many of whom are based in California, forcing other candidates out of the race.

Traditionally, Democrat White House hopefuls treat California, with its wealthy Hollywood and Silicon Valley donors, as a giant campaign cash machine, but the donors may now favour someone from there.

And in what promises to be a very large field that is a huge boost to at least three serious contenders who already have power bases in the state.

Chief among them is Kamala Harris, the state's former attorney general, who has been lauded by Democrats during her first term as a US senator in Washington.

She has been vocal in quizzing members of the Trump administration at Senate hearings and PredictIt, the online political stock market, now rates her chances higher than anybody else, including former Vice President Joe Biden and the 2016 contender Bernie Sanders.

Eric Garcetti, the former Mayor of Los Angeles, is also attracting attention.

And then there is Jerry Brown, California's current Governor who, ironically, will be the person signing the change of primary date into law.

Enthusiasm for a run by Mr Brown, 79, is growing. It would be his fourth tilt at the White House, having first tried in 1976. In 1992 he came second to Bill Clinton.

During a previous stint as Governor of California in the 1970s and 1980s he was known as "Governor Moonbeam" because of his enthusiasm for the space programme, and dated the singer Linda Ronsdtat.

Other Californian contenders who could benefit include Tom Steyer, the Democrats' biggest mega-donor in 2016.

The San Francisco-based hedge fund billionaire and climate-change activist gave nearly $100 million last time. This time he has indicated he may just run himself.

Barack Obama's first speech since stepping down as president 02:16

Another California-based billionaire, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, has also set tongues wagging.

For the non-Californian runners moving the primary puts minor candidates at a further disadvantage, with large resources needed to fund criss-crossing of the state, and expensive television adverts.

That would benefit major players like Mr Sanders, who is likely to try again, and Mr Biden, who seems to regret not running last time.

The focus on California would also shift the entire Democrat race to the left as candidates woo an electorate much more liberal than in Iowa and New Hampshire.

More than half the Hispanic people in the US are in California, and the environment would becomes a key issue in the race, the state having recently suffered an epochal drought.

The shift to the left is already apparent. Several of the 2020 contenders, including Kamala Harris, have publicly backed a plan launched this week by Mr Sanders for universal government funded healthcare, which Mrs Clinton previously declared too radical.

Other potential 2020 contenders supporting the plan include Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, a high profile critic of Mr Trump,New Jersey senator Cory Booker, and New York senator Kirsten Gillibrand.

Only one candidate has formally declared already.

John Delaney, a US congressman from Maryland, and a self-made businessman worth $215 million, hoped to get a jump on the competiton by announcing his candidacy more than two years before the first primary vote.

He told the Sunday Telegraph: "I think am the right person for the job, but not enough people know that. So the way I solve that problem is by getting in early."
